Law School.
Hello, Emily.
Hey, David.
And John Dickerson continues to contemplate the navel of the universe on vacation or something.

ever met.
Ben Wittes.
Hello, Ben.

possible crimes by former President Trump?
Well, we actually haven't learned that much.
We've learned that there was some highly classified information there.

around Trump or Trump himself as to the disposition of the material that he retained from the
White House.
We've learned that there are a lot of rumors about the nature of the information in question.
We don't really know to this day why it is that the FBI and the Justice Department,
up to and including the Attorney General, thought this was a matter of extreme urgency
or what the true aggravating factors were that caused this to result in an executed search warrant.
I think we're still waiting for the other shoe to drop on that.
Is there going to be another shoe?
Are we going to find all these things out, we, the public, or not necessarily, Emily?
I mean, eventually, but not necessarily soon because the government is opposing releasing
the affidavit that would give the underlying facts that would actually explain to us more

step of searching the residents of a former president and also a little more or somewhat

that are missing.
And I'm curious what Ben thinks.
I mean, I have very mixed feelings about whether we should find out any of this.
This whole half in the shadow is a little bit of information about an investigation that
is not yet produced in indictment.
It just makes me nervous.
It goes back to Jim Comey releasing some information about the investigation of Hillary

It's not how the FBI usually does business.

And yet the government has stopped short of the specifics that would really explain to
people what's going on.
I do not have a problem with what the Justice Department has done so far.
It seems to me the equities here are not privacy equities on the part of Donald Trump.
They are investigative secrecy equities on the part of the FBI and the Justice Department.
And the Justice Department isn't dishing information about Donald Trump.
It's simply moved to release the search warrant and the inventory steps that Donald Trump
himself didn't oppose.
So they haven't released anything, the release of which Trump did not consent to.
And it seems to me if they want to draw the line there and say, hey, we're not ready to

Had they not already decided that this was a matter that they were prepared to see through

a crime?
Could the recovery just be the end of it all?

Adoretically, you are absolutely right.

And I just don't believe these people are that stupid.

We're joined for this segment by Dana Goldstein.
She is a national reporter at the New York Times covering education.
It's like being a war correspondent where there's a battle, there's always a battle
in education.
And in particular, we want to talk today about the battle over how kids learn to read and
how they should learn to read.
There is a ton of evidence, which Dana will tell us about, I think, that kids learn to
read in a particular way.
And yet even after a generation of this being known, a lot of American kids in our schools
are not learning that way.
We have reading scores that are way down post-pandemic and we have reading also now
being caught up in the culture war.
So there is a ton of ferment about reading and how kids learn to read at this very moment.
And we want to talk to Dana about that.
So, Dana, can you start by telling us what the science of reading to use a phrase that
is apparently now popular tells us about how kids learn to read and how long we have known
that it tells us that?
So the science of reading is sort of a catch phrase that's being used by a group of educators
and parents who have become activists for teaching reading in a new way.
And they are asking that reading be taught according to what is known by research in
terms of how the human brain learns to read.
It has been known since about the late 1960s that phonemic awareness and phonics play a
crucial role in how children learn to read.
That is basically the connections between the letters on the page and the sounds we hear
every day in spoken language.
To speak is natural.
It's human.
We will learn to speak and communicate through listening and being around other people who
are speaking.
It is not natural to learn how to read.
Our brains have evolved to be able to do that much more recently.
It's not sort of innate to our species to learn to read.
In order to read we have to understand there is a connection between the words that surround
us that we hear and what we see.
So for example we need to know that ST goes st.
So all these are actually rules that can be taught to children explicitly.
And it turns out that research shows that teaching that quite explicitly, you know, going through
those letters and letter combinations and the sounds they make.
And yes, there is a regularity in English.
Some of the irregular sounds and combinations are going through that explicitly teaching

Yet that is not sort of the predominant way that American teachers are trained to teach
children to read.
So you've written a lot about this in an incredibly fair-minded way, I think.
There's also a piece in the last week from Time magazine by Belinda Luscombe.
And she has a kind of amazing, I thought, quote at the top of this piece.
She's talking about the point of view of a teacher in Oakland, California, Kareem Weaver.

Weaver has renounced this position.

And the fight is always about what this balance should be, right?
Yeah.
I mean, effective reading teaching is not ever going to be just phonics.
It's going to be starting with phonics in kindergarten, maybe preschool, combining that

of what they read is knowledge building.

It can be done sometimes in 15, 20 or 30 minutes per day in kindergarten and first

I think, yes, there are some teachers who resist this, especially in the beginning when

And there's a few reasons why.
This sort of dominant ideology in teachers' colleges and in teacher education in this

What that means is that there's a belief that children construct their own knowledge of

If you let kids follow their own curiosity, they are going to find knowledge.

All that is true for some group of children.
It is not true for all kids.
It's certainly not true for those who are dyslexic, for example, which is a pretty significantly
common disability.
